number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
y 4, 2015
												Let me just start by saying the Alpha Protocol is one of the few RPGs I know that have delivered on it's 'choice changes the game' mechanic. I've played this game for 80 hours now, and I can say that there's cutscenes I have seen in LPs that I haven't even played before.GameplayHonestly, this isn't the best combat I've ever seen. You can play with stealth, or just shoot everything in the face. You start off with 4 classes to choose from which have perk points already in some predetermined places, but you can mix them up. A 5th option, Recruit, has you starting with no perk points at all, making the game a lot harder. Completing the Recruit option will unlock Veteran for future playthroughs, who has perks from previous experience.You can carry two weapons with you at a time, ranging from an assault rifle, a shotgun, an smg and a pistol. They can be upgraded and you can even buy more of them in the safehouse.The safehouse serves as a hub for you inbetween missions, allowing you to read your emails (which sometimes contain funding or other useful information), watch TV about 'recent affairs', or check the black market. On the black market you can buy things ranging from a map of the complex to intelligence on a person.You can build up intel on people or groups, and knowing it can sometimes give you an extra option in conversations. They also give you a certain damage bonus against some of the bosses.StorySPOILERS:The story begins with you, Mike Thorton, waking up in a secret government facility. You break out, only to find that it was a test of your abilities. You are sent off to Saudi Arabia, to recover stolen Halbech missiles. A terrorist group has stolen them, and they used them to blow up a civillian plane earlier. There will be sequences where you are sat in a room talking to a man about what you have just done. The idea is that the missions happened months ago, and you're being interrogated now. You will learn in Saudi that the missiles were never stolen, they were given freely by Halbech. With the help of an agent, Mina, who is still operating in the AP facility, you escape, and quickly realise that Halbech are attempting to spark a war, so that they can ramp up production and earn more money. Off the data you take with you you find that there are three major Halbech locations. They are Rome, Taipei and Moscow. You can visit them in any order, but the game will change considerably based on which one you go to. After collecting information on Halbech, you have to return to the AP base to finish it all. Based on if you romanced anyone or you were good friends with them and they survived, they will join you on a final boatride into the sunset.VerdictThe story is extremely well written and has a very high replayability, only being dragged down by the combat. For that, I'll give it an 7/10

content:
er 21, 2014
												Great game but it could have been so much more.  Good:It's a spy shooter that let's you play the way you want, stealth, guns blazing, etc.  An RPG skill system can be used to bolster your play style, for example developing lock pickking, silent running, rifles, explosives, etc. Your choices in and out of combat give you influence with various characters and ultimately decide how the story unfolds and how the game ends. Bad:It was obviously dumbed down for consoles.  Some of the hacking mini games are annoyingAlthough the story is good, some of the choices are forced a la Mass Effect, choose who dies.Worse, it does so, by commiting the ultimate gameplay sin where you win a battle, but lose in a cutscene.Overall.  I love the game, but it could have been so much better.  As with many Obsidian games, the final execution just isn't quite there.  When will game makers understand that the real art isn't forcing us to choose who dies.  It's in allowing us to discover how to save both, or maybe not to be the hero and let them all die.  Still, highly worth playing.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
, 2015
												Controls are clunky and painful, protagonist has an absurdly annoying voice that you will immediately be sick of, when the player walks around while crouching it's one of the most comical animations I've ever seen, and the shooting mechanics suuuuuck.But it's still one of my favorite games, becaaauuse...1. It balances player choice with a smooth narrative. No matter what direction you choose, the story always compensates and fills in the gaps with finesse.2. The skills actually reward you by giving you crappy skills to begin with. You start out as a top operative but can't shoot worth a damn, and then after several missions and a few upgrades, you're finally getting the hang of things and notice a dramatic improvement in the mechanics.3. The supporting characters dynamically react to how you treat them. This is the closest we will get to scripted AI dialogue where our responses affect the NPC's attitudes and behaviors in conversations and remain consistent throughout the game unless you resolve the conflicts.4. Gun modifications make sense and follow a semblance of realism, which isn't unpopular nowadays but adds a nice addition to the game.This is a super toned down version of Just Cause with fantastically crafted dialogue. And right now it's 3 bucks. You have no reason to not buy this game.

												One of the greatest RPGs I've had the fortune to play. The combat/stealth (Yes, a main selling point) leaves a lot to be desired, but as for the rest of the game, it couldn't be more spot on. It plays somewhat like Mass Effect, but I thought the story was much, much nicer, and the choices you make in this game actually impact the route that the rest of the game takes, instead of just giving you a different ending depending on X% of nice paths chosen vs X% of evil paths chosen.I'd say this game could go for $40-45. $60 would be a bit much, seeing as the combat/stealth portion is quite flawed, but I'd agree with up to $45. And guess what? It's only $15. You're getting an absolute steal here. (Note: I have multiple playthroughs of this, but for some reason time tracking didn't start until the end of my last playthrough. I probably have nearly 35-40 hours in it at the moment.)

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
y 24, 2014
												What are you looking at? A James Bond clone? An attempt at a good RPG Bourne Game? Obsidian taking an stab at something original? No. Yes. Yes. This game, is not like any other game. It makes Fallout look like a dingleberry on Metacritic scores. It turns your Mass Effect into Mass Defect. No other game exists like "Alpha Protocol", no game can exist like this game.Let me start with the story: You're a new recruit, brought onto the team to take out a major threat. That's it. Fine details don't matter. The gameplay? Have you ever had a McFlurry? Ever stuffed one down your pants? It's that exciting. The gameplay has animations, created from the hands of gods. Smooth Kung-Fu fighting, to Stopping Time and killing enemies with locked targets. RPG elements? Oh man it's got em. Dialogue choices are no joke, and really effect the tree of possible outcomes. You're also timed, so drop that blunt and focus breh! It's amazing to see how you can be suave, professional, or a complete ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥. Or if you play your cards right, you can be all three!Music: Groovy. I want the soundtrack. 'nuff said.Customization: Oh man, you can literally be ANYTHING! Beard with hat, beard without hat, huge beard. It's the beards that gets me. I don't even care about the eye color, if I can have the beard of Vikings, while killing terrorists. Final Thoughts: Alpha Portocol is a really ambitious RPG. If you like the Espionage theme, give the game a shot. It has its problems, and could use WAY more polish, but through that, it's a really great game. The story can take many different turns based off your choices, and the game is also designed for replayability. I haven't beaten Fallout: New Vegas or Mass Effect 3. I have beaten Alpha Protocol.

content:
er 21, 2014
												Great game but it could have been so much more.  Good:It's a spy shooter that let's you play the way you want, stealth, guns blazing, etc.  An RPG skill system can be used to bolster your play style, for example developing lock pickking, silent running, rifles, explosives, etc. Your choices in and out of combat give you influence with various characters and ultimately decide how the story unfolds and how the game ends. Bad:It was obviously dumbed down for consoles.  Some of the hacking mini games are annoyingAlthough the story is good, some of the choices are forced a la Mass Effect, choose who dies.Worse, it does so, by commiting the ultimate gameplay sin where you win a battle, but lose in a cutscene.Overall.  I love the game, but it could have been so much better.  As with many Obsidian games, the final execution just isn't quite there.  When will game makers understand that the real art isn't forcing us to choose who dies.  It's in allowing us to discover how to save both, or maybe not to be the hero and let them all die.  Still, highly worth playing.

content:
ry 1, 2015
												Alpha Protocol... What an odd game to be reviewing. This game has average AI, Bad combat, clunky animation, stealth that is ruined by invisibility and guns that feel like pea-shooters. Yet, the dialog, choices, and story, somehow manage to make this game compelling and a blast to play. The guns suck, but the shotguns are somewhat fun to use once you charge them up. The melee combat is a bit odd just run up and punch someone two or three times and they are out, or sneak kill/knock-out. Honestly, this is one of the best games there is, but SEGA constantly changing what type of game they wanted made it a bit of a mess. But even though it is a mess, its like a Jackson Pollock painting.Sure it isn't the most amazing game of all time, but it is worth a play through. Just keep in mind, this is an RPG, not a TPS.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
ry 23, 2014
												Great dialogue system, decent writing but incredibly lackluster gameplay barring dialogue. It feels like a master of a certain rare trait for RPGs; well-written and architectured player-NPC interaction in a cinematic format. Sadly it falls short in almost every single other department. The promise of challenging stealth initially invited me to try this game, but the only challenge presented is poor AI and a plethora of bugs. Success or failure is so easily attributed to poor design that neither feels rewarding nor punishing. Doing missions guns blazing suffers from the same effect. Character and environmental design is surprisingly poor considering the quality of the writing, usually the art department for games like this trumps the writing department. Playing this game felt like a grind for the dialogue segments, the plot itself becomes dry and predictable halfway through. I was really uncertain whether I would recommend this game or not, but other players might have a higher tolerance for the above drawbacks and the particular kind of dialogue system the game offers is still the best in its' genre. [5/10]

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
y 24, 2014
												What are you looking at? A James Bond clone? An attempt at a good RPG Bourne Game? Obsidian taking an stab at something original? No. Yes. Yes. This game, is not like any other game. It makes Fallout look like a dingleberry on Metacritic scores. It turns your Mass Effect into Mass Defect. No other game exists like "Alpha Protocol", no game can exist like this game.Let me start with the story: You're a new recruit, brought onto the team to take out a major threat. That's it. Fine details don't matter. The gameplay? Have you ever had a McFlurry? Ever stuffed one down your pants? It's that exciting. The gameplay has animations, created from the hands of gods. Smooth Kung-Fu fighting, to Stopping Time and killing enemies with locked targets. RPG elements? Oh man it's got em. Dialogue choices are no joke, and really effect the tree of possible outcomes. You're also timed, so drop that blunt and focus breh! It's amazing to see how you can be suave, professional, or a complete ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥. Or if you play your cards right, you can be all three!Music: Groovy. I want the soundtrack. 'nuff said.Customization: Oh man, you can literally be ANYTHING! Beard with hat, beard without hat, huge beard. It's the beards that gets me. I don't even care about the eye color, if I can have the beard of Vikings, while killing terrorists. Final Thoughts: Alpha Portocol is a really ambitious RPG. If you like the Espionage theme, give the game a shot. It has its problems, and could use WAY more polish, but through that, it's a really great game. The story can take many different turns based off your choices, and the game is also designed for replayability. I haven't beaten Fallout: New Vegas or Mass Effect 3. I have beaten Alpha Protocol.

On the other hand, it's a pretty unique Action-RPG hybrid with a flexible role-playing system, engaging branching storyline with morally ambiguous choices to make, and a lot of replay options through both action and dialog via the cause and effect system. I'd still say give Alpha Protocol a try, especially whenever it's on sale.

content:
ber 26, 2014
												I finished this game like 4 times before buying it from Steam (Or, perhaps, I got it with a Humble Bundle. I don't remember correctly) and I enjoyed every single bit of it.You play as Michael Thorton, a brilliant and promising trainee to join the ranks of Alpha Protocol, a secret agency. Prove everyone and yourself that you're the best agents around. As the world around you seems to collapse, you always find a way out.Introducing a similar, but much more interactive, dialogue system like Mass Effect, you decide the attitude you want Michael to have towards people, depending the personalities of the others and what you have read in their dossiers.Be a spy lurking in the shadows or a tough soldier ramping your way inside compounds and bases. This amazing third person shooter game also have RPG elements allowing you to make the agent you want to be.The story is not so long, I think. Depending on the difficulty, 20 hours should be enough for you to finish it.Perhaps you've heard about some bugs and glitches this game have. I will not deny it, it's not a perfect game. As everything, it has some flaws. But, trust me, it's an experience hard to forget.Would I recommend it? Hell, yes!So, feel free to buy it, my friend. I'm sure that, if you like RPG's, you will totally love it.

content:
, 2016
Alpha Protocol™ is an overlooked gem of an RPG. Alpha Protocol™ is the whole package. A branching story, filled with multiple game-changing decisions. Each mission has more than one approach to it. Weapons and gear customization. Story: You play as agent Michael Thorton, tasked with his first Alpha Protocol mission. Things, however, are much different from what they seem to be, as Thorton becomes involved in a conspiracy. The story features many turns and twists and yes, you can be evil as much, as you want to.  Gameplay: Alpha Protocol™, however, is plagued in its gameplay. While you can opt for a stealthy campaign, you're still forced into close combat and horrible boss encounters.  Movement is detailed, you can climb walls, crouch, vault over. However, it is also restricted. You can do those things only where the game says you can.  Shooting, on the other hand, is terrible, but this plays a part in the character progression. Depending on what skills you decide to improve on, shooting can be enjoyable. As mentioned above, there is character progression. These are upgradable skills, which can influence your experience with the game and, combined with the dialogue choice, encourage multiple playthroughs. Sum up: So is Alpha Protocol™ worth checking out? Yes, definitely. While the gameplay is a mixed bag, the story is worth it. Give this one a try,

However, if one fraction favors you, you may have issues with those who oppose it- choose wisely! The point? Must buy.

												I must buck the trend and say I adored this game. I finished it three times doing every conceivable option and character build. The faction system forged through real character choices is fantastic. The dialogue system keeps things interesting as well. Likewise, I actually loved the combat system, although the game was too easy. Also, AP has perfect pacing; levels never drag on and the game keeps you interested until the end. I only experienced a few minor bugs, so I really can't relate to all these complaints. To me AP will go down as one of the most under-appreciated games ever. To each his or her own, but if you can look past the hate and ignore the quirks, you too might just become obsessed with being Michael Thorton.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
er 29, 2012
												Alpha Protocol. The game that got killed by the "professional" reviewers that never bothered to get past the tutorial, in most cases. Most of them admited years later their mistake. Behind its roughness, AP has, probably, the best choices and consequences system that you will ever encounter in a video game, with only The Witcher series and Fallout 1/2 being on par or better. Marketing did not help this game, either. Sega presented this puppy as an adventure/shooter game. But AP is an RPG. You have skills and abilities that will affect combat and gameplay. You want better shooting/aiming/etc, you will have to invest in the respective skills. But this game is so much more than an action RPG. What you are saying in the conversation matters. The attitude matters. The skills you take. The background you get for your character.I've played my DVD to hell an back, as the game offers a lot of replayability. Got it on Steam as a backup solution. My most satisfying walkthrough was me playing as a plain spy. No armor, stealth, hand to hand combat that is incapacitating the enemy (the usual crawl and subdue), playing with words and guessing the right answers for the people you will encounter, transforming enemies into allies. At the end of the playthrough i had behind me a small army ready to help. From zero to hero. That was something and took me a couple of playthroughs to get that result. The graphics are still standing. The sound, well, you will encounter some glitches but just check the Obsidian forums for some working fixes. The hacking mini-game is bad, but it can be bearable after applying some fixes available on the aforementioned forum. The worst bug of the game: saving when you are crouching in cover and discovering on loading that you are fully exposed. If i would recommend it?! In a hearbeat! But keep in mind: this is an RPG not a shooter. And if you want for your weapon to work as intended, you need to invest points in that weapon. But as a wise man said: a spy that needs to draw a weapon means that he made a mistake somewhere down the road. Your name is not Rambo, nor Bond. Think more like Michael Westen from Burn Notice.

												This game didn't deserve all the hate it got. It's a pretty decent RPG where choices in friends play an important role. I put all of my points into stealth, and now I'm stuck in an open gunfight with an insane boss. This sucks."  There are a small number of bosses like this, but enough to make it a real hassle. content:

												This game got a seriously bad rap. It's not the best third-person shooter I've played, and oftentimes one might run into an annoying bug, but overall it's a game that offers a lot.Espionage isn't the most investigated genre in the gaming industry, at least not to this level - and Obsidian did a good job of it. Globe-trotting, stealth missions, lethal or non-lethal methodologies - it's a good example of a good game being lambasted unfairly by the general public.The dialogue and choice system are top-notch and can vastly change the playthrough from one game to the next. Most comparable to the dialogue system in Mass Effect, how you treat others can have serious ramifications long down the road; choices made when conversing with one character may completely alter the conversation you have with another several chapters later. A very impressive achievement, and one that seems to have flown under the radar of most.Highly recommended.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
ber 6, 2011
												After finishing this game, I really don't understand why it got such a panning - it's great!I'll start with the not-so-good stuff first:•	The AI isn't great, and•	The boss battles are insanely unfairThat's it.Alpha Protocol is an espionage RPG/shooter, but really - first and foremost - it's a great story well told. It offers choices that have real consequence, and it allows you to play it out however you see fit.All out action? Sneaky stealth? A combination of both? You can tailor your character to suit your play style. I'm a sneaky ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ at heart, so I chose a Specialist, with Stealth and Martial Arts as my lead attributes ;)You want to kill everyone you come across? You can. Prefer to be non-lethal and just use a painful take-down instead? You can do that too. That assassin that tried to kill you, you want to kill or spare it? Again, up to you, and each choice will affect the story.Conversations I found a blast, with usually 3-4 options as a reply - 'Joking', 'Suave', 'Professional', 'Tender', 'Taunt', 'Antagonise', 'Execute'... Each response can have its pro's and con's, whether positive or negative, and affects how the other person will react to you in the future. It looks pretty good, while not spectacular. The look is very 'clean', and there is a few clipping instances, but I really didn't find anything that marred my experience. I'm not sure how many hours it took to complete, as the Steam hours counter didn't work on quite a few of my plays. I would say around 20-25, though. I played the game using an Xbox 360 pad, so I can't really comment on the mouse/keyboard controls, but from what I've read, the pad is the way to play, really.I paid £5 for this in the Steam Sale, but I really wouldn't have felt cheated if I paid full whack for it. It really is a shame it was received the way it was, and that the sales reflected this. I would have loved another slice. It's a good job multiple playthroughs are catered for... :D

content:
er 23, 2010
												It's like Bioware and Obsidian had a baby. The gameplay and npc dialogue will leave you reminiscent of Mass Effect, while the story will probably remind you of Obsidian's inability to put together a decent story. At least this game has an ending. Several, in fact, which all depend on actions you take through the game, as opposed to one important decision made at the end. Even though it's marketed as a stealth rpg, you are free to go in guns blazing, although that will punish you through means of severely reduced mission rewards and your allies either hating you or loving you for it. Think Dragon Age's approval system, where some of your allies might look down upon killing police officers, while others might encourage you to take down anyone in your way. In a way, this is an interesting game mechanic, as there are some npcs you might want to hate you for story related reasons.Overall, a solid game that didn't get the appreciation it deserved when it first came out.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
r 18, 2011
												Alpha Protocol, Obsidian's only original IP to date, is an RPG built on familiar mechanics with an interesting "Bourne Identity" style spy premise. Like RPGs of old, combat and dialogue are so separate as to almost comprise different games within the same narrative, but each is gratifying and reasonably well executed.What distinguishes Alpha Protocol from similar stealth-action-RPGs are the branching choices. It is impossible to anticipate the consequences of your decisions, and even minor dialogue choices can potentially have game-changing ramifications.The voice acting ranges from fair to excellent, and the graphics, although dated, convey the setting well enough. The soundtrack occasionally becomes repetitive, but its not a deal breaker.Like all of Obsidian's work, AP remains very rough around the edges. Expect bugs, glitches, and design flaws to creep into your game every hour or two. If you can work through the flaws, there's a gem here that shouldn't be missed.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
, 2013
												A game I both love and hate in equal measure. The combat is janky and unbalanced as all get out and animations/texture quality can be laughable at times. The hacking minigame is unspeakably awful.It's also one of the finest modern RPGs from this generation. It far eclipses what Mass Effect tried to do in terms of it's dialogue system and how characters react to your actions. The dossier system actually ties back into the game and the options you're given rather than being extra lore reading. And the sheer amount of reactivity to your choices and the consequences that can result put Mass Effect to shame, causing genuinely different endings based on how you play - sometimes drastically different. There isn't a blue, red, or green light to be found. The beginning takes patience to trudge through, but once you're past the Saudi Arabia hub the game begins to shine.

content:
er 26, 2011
												Obsidian's Alpha Protocol offers an original setting and the power of choice. It's a game where you decide the fate of a majority of the cast, giving you the sense that the story is guided as much by you as it is by the designers. With a number of ways to customize the experience – you can play as a stealth agent with a silenced pistol or bullet-spraying berserker – it is an entertaining role-playing experience with some little flaws. One of the best story telling experiences I had in a game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
y 27, 2013
												Alpha Protocol is a game not without flaws, some of which can be noticeable and frustrating. The gunplay is unpolished and for the most part not very enjoyable. Enemy AI can be inconsistent, especially when it comes to the stealth aspects of the game. Some of the in-game animations can be painful to watch (I get back pains just thinking about the sneak/crouch animation). It's also known to have its fair share of bugs and glitches.Having said all that, Alpha Protocol is still a fantastic action-RPG that I absolutely adored. It all starts with the timed dialogue system which offers several choices and forces you to think fast and pay close attention to the characters on-screen. Just about every decision you make can have an impact on the game going forward and cause the story to branch off in noticably different directions. Combined with the ability to tackle levels in various orders (which in turn influences how the story unfolds), you could play the game multiple times and have each playthrough be unique. The amount of freedom you're given over the course of the game is huge and quite refreshing.The writing and story-telling are also bright spots. The complex story is full of conspiracy, coverups and espionage. The numerous characters you'll encounter along the way are generally interesting and well-written, most of which have lengthy backstories that you might not be able to uncover in a single playthrough. It's the kind of quality work you'd expect from Obsidian.And while the sneaking mechanics can be janky at times, going the stealth route is still a whole lot of fun. Executing non-lethal take-downs and maneuvering through levels quiety and undetected is a satisfying feeling. Focusing on stealth/pistol gameplay and playing the Sam Fisher role is the preferred way to go and helps improve the gameplay exponentially.Given its flaws and inconsistencies, Alpha Protocol is (understandably) a game not everyone will enjoy. However, I feel that if you can look past its problems and appreciate the unique aspects of the game, you can really enjoy the product that Obsidian created. In my opinion it's one of the finer and most underrated RPGs of the last few years.

You also don't get absolute freedom in how to go about accomplishing the mission; you can't make Mike into a bad guy without some serious contradictions of character.Other thoughts: It is not an open-world RPG so don't expect to be able to play past the ending. Other than that this is quite possibly one of the most underrated spy-RPGs ever. I blame the bugs.

content:
er 29, 2013
												Alpha Protocol...now here is a game that slipped under most people's radar. The fellows that brought you Fallout: New Vegas were working on this project before Fallout and you can see a bit of their humor and influence bleed through. Unique in it's subject matter, Alpha Protocol is a Spy RPG, with Mass Effect style dialouge trees. While I expected to be playing some low rent James Bond knockoff what I managed to get was something closer to "Archer" than "Peter Gunn". This game has a beautiful sense of humor and a fun albeit somewhat truncated and confusing story. Make your agent, select his background, then either shoot your way, stealth your way, or smoothe talk your way through one of the more unique RPG's of it's era. I would say, give Alpha Protocol a try, it could suprise you.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
er 27, 2013
												from the zero punctuation review"There have been many RPGs that let you define your character's personality to a certain extent. Say you're given a quest to get a schoolgirl's cat down from a tree. On average, you'll be given three options: neutral, where you get the cat down and accept the schoolgirl's allowance as payment; good, where you waive the fee and fondly tousle the schoolgirl's hair as she scampers off; and ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, where you set fire to the tree and jump up and down on the schoolgirl's face.And speaking as an ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, this offends me. There are so many wonderful ways to be a complete ponce that these games rarely cater for. Why can't I rescue the cat but hold it to ransom for her dad's porn collection? Or get the cat down by throwing rocks at it so it breaks all its legs on the concrete and then still expect to be paid, with the infuriatingly infallible logic of a complete tosser? Why can't there be an RPG that covers the entire ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ spectrum? Well, good news, ponce fans: now there is!Alpha Protocol follows Mike Thorton, a member of a covert U.S. government agency with strong ties to a private military company that might as well rename itself Kitten Stranglers PLC. He gets betrayed, goes rogue, has to work alone to build a case against them, blahdee blahdee blah. But what's important is that however you play him Mike Thorton is the is the ponciest ponce that ever ponced past a poncing parlour.The dialogue system lets you switch between three attitudes: a professional, by the book sort of ponce who wouldn't emote if the angel Gabriel blow off in his face; an aggressive ponce who sounds like he's five seconds away from snarlingly flipping the global crisis onto its front and pounding away at its netherhole with a Franchi SPAS-12; and the suave ponce, who might as well just save time and mace himself every time he opens his ♥♥♥♥ing mouth. Best of all, even if he only ever talked about his favorite breakfast cereal, he'd still sound like a ♥♥♥♥♥♥, because the voice actor delivers every line in the level, smug tones of a highbrow film critic archly dismissing the latest superhero blockbuster as he spoons himself another helping of baby seal.Let's get the good over with quickly. For once, this is a game that claims that "every action has consequences" and actually means a consequence more significant than a character maybe wearing a different hat. For example, although the hub-based mission system lets you do the operations in any order, during the one I chose to do last an informant mentioned the previous operations I'd completed in conversation. "♥♥♥♥," I said, "this game's just showing off now." So I immediately became an aggressive ponce and slammed his head into a desk. After which, there was more security in my next mission because the informant went crying to his big brother or something.The RPG action stuff reminded me of Deus Ex - in a good way. It's nice to see a game where your character has to work on their gun skills and can't expect to draw their pistol and immediately hit the on button on a tumble dryer from nine hundred years. And I was also impressed by the lockpicking and hacking minigames, which nicely balance skill and incremental difficulty, and I can't think of a joke for that sentence, so here's a picture of a dog in a hat.The thing about Deus Ex, though, was that you could arguably specialize completely in combat or stealth or hacking or playing the cello and still beat the game. Even the final encounter had equal parts monsters, security systems, and incomplete string quartets to allow any approach. Alpha Protocol, on the other hand, is happy to let you sink all your points into learning to waltz only to find yourself stuck in an unavoidable freestyle disco competition. I was a stealth/close combat specialist, and there was this particularly obnoxious boss fight that I couldn't sneak out of and whose CQC attacks wrecked my ♥♥♥♥. I had to inexpertly spray at him with an assault rifle I knew as much about as I did a ♥♥♥♥ing nuclear reactor, then whenever he got his knives out let him chase me around the room like Benny ♥♥♥♥ing Hill!The skills you can upgrade are stealth, hand-to-hand combat, and then four kinds of guns, which I feel makes little sense. Why the ♥♥♥♥ would anyone specialise in shotguns when a shotgun is a situational weapon? What are you gonna do if there's an enemy more than ten feet away, throw your shoes at him?The dialogue system gives you about one second to pick a conversational attitude that is summed up in one word, and it's often hard to decipher. You might be talking to a sexy lady, for e.g., when suddenly an option comes up reading, say, "Trousers." And there's no way of knowing if this means the poncemaster general will change the conversation to the subject of trousers or draw attention to a specific pair of trousers sneaking up behind them or whatever. So you select it out of panic, whereupon El Ponco promptly pulls his trousers down and slaps his bum while mooing like a lost calf, spoiling your reputation with the character somewhat.Dialogue seems a bit buggy at times, too, which I guess is inevitable with conversation trees as labyrinthine as this. There was a moment when I was gabbing away with another sexy lady when the option came up to initiate a quick knobbing, which went down reasonably well. Then afterwards she started repeating dialogue lines she'd been spouting beforehand. "Wow," I thought, "I literally ♥♥♥♥ed her brain out!"There are a couple of other bugs here and there, like how the distinction between a wall you can take cover on and the ones with ponce-repellent wallpaper is known only to Mr. Thorton. But none of them got in the way too much, because after a while my stealth skill was so high I could literally turn invisible and run around insta-killing every possible threat with my bare hands. And nothing could pose a challenge after that, short of the invention of some kind of ponce-seeking missile.All in all, Alpha Protocol is weak and poorly balanced, like a three-legged dog with an eating disorder. But I want to come back to the story for a bit. You know that extremely brief summary I gave about five paragraphs ago? That's literally the extent of the plot I understood. The rest was an incomprehensible miasma of factions, motivations, and betrayals, through which I was just dumbly acting with zero understanding. Towards the end, a line of dialogue got drowned out just before a boss encounter, and I honestly didn't know if I was supposed to be killing or protecting the guy. Maybe this would be helped through repeat playthroughs; oh, Sega, you crafty ♥♥♥♥♥es!"

content:
er 20, 2013
												This game isn't perfect: it has its share of glitches, and just getting it to run can be quite the hassle.  It's worth the effort, though.  Besides the solid gameplay that allows you to pick virtually any approach with equal effectiveness, it shines head and shoulders above every other game in making your decisions meaningful.  Everything you say can have both large and small impacts on the future of the game, to the point that you can play it a dozen times and not see everything.  And that's no exaggeration - I've done it.  The game is that satisying.The technical issues mean I can't give this game a strictly positive review, but if you can get past them, you'll find an incredibly solid and immersive game that will continue to surprise you even after several playthroughs.

content:
er 3, 2010
												First of all.. If you ever played Deus Ex and liked it, this is the game for you. If you didn't, you may very well still like it for a number of reasons.. If you like to sneak around, taking out enemies from behind with awesome takedowns or kills, this is the game for you. If you like a short, but actionfilled story that adapts to the way you play the game, this is the game for you. If you like charging in, guns blazin' and shooting everything with assault rifles, shotguns, SMGs or whatever, this is the game for you. This game has SO many options on how to play, act, etc., that a lot of people enjoys some aspect of it.Personally I loved it, because everything you do, every choice you make, every answer you give, and every question you ask, have an impact on the storyline, which makes it a large web of events, tangling together, to create an epic feeling, forcing you to think on your feet, and actually pay attention to what happens around you, and the information you're given.

content:
y 14, 2011
												Alpha Protocol is immediately underwhelming with unatmospheric graphics and a depressingly unoriginal opening (you wake up with amnesia and are talked through a training level) devoid of excitement, pacing, intrigue, spectacle or interest. Your dreary avatar humorously crouch-walks around the level giving you time to wonder why game designers have the bizarre belief that we bought a game about secret agents to be treated like an infant. We're supposed to be amazing; the game and characters should treat us as such in order to instil the relevant atmosphere. The problems with the game are legion; most notably, cover that frequently doesn't work, every boss fight being an exercise in gut-punching misery (despite one being brilliantly backed by Turn Up the Radio by Autograph) and being generally forced to choose a response before you hear enough of the lead-in. Additionally, the presence of sexual swear words feels wrong given the inspiration is clearly the bad-language-free JB spy gods o

												I must buck the trend and say I adored this game. I finished it three times doing every conceivable option and character build. The faction system forged through real character choices is fantastic. The dialogue system keeps things interesting as well. Likewise, I actually loved the combat system, although the game was too easy. Also, AP has perfect pacing; levels never drag on and the game keeps you interested until the end. I only experienced a few minor bugs, so I really can't relate to all these complaints. To me AP will go down as one of the most under-appreciated games ever. To each his or her own, but if you can look past the hate and ignore the quirks, you too might just become obsessed with being Michael Thorton.

												A game world that reacts to what you do.That's what a number of RPG-type gamers I've talked to want. They want their choices to make a difference to the plot. That's what Alpha Protocol is about. The things you do will be acknowledged. The way you do them will be noticed.The combat system is easy to break, the game needed much more time in testing, and you really want a 360 controller for this. It is extremely buggy at times. But the underlying principle of this game is choice, and you get a lot of it.Also there's a cocaine-fueled boss fight to the dulcent strains of "Turn Up The Radio" by Autograph, Nolan North playing an insane man with a bottle of bleach, and the ability to be as friendly or as big of an ♥♥♥ as you want to several extremely powerful people.

content:
20, 2011
												Alpha Protocol is what would happen if James Bond and cover shooters had a slightly autistic RPG baby.  It's game where everything works as advertised, and yet somehow doesn't..If you love to run-and-gun, sneak your way through a level, or dispatch enemies with a wide variety of useful gadgets and tools then this is not really the game for you.  All these things are in the game, but only just enough to work, not enough to entertain.  The mechanics are largely broken with pistols being so powerful as to be game-breaking, and guns like the assault rifle so ♥♥♥♥♥♥ that it has trouble dispatching even the most basic of foes.  Gadgets are crap to worthless.On the other hand if you love the idea of a storyline so malleable that almost any detail can be altered or changed, any character befriended or shot dead (even major NPCs, all the way down to changing the final boss) and shockingly engrossing, snappily written social sequences then Alpha Protocol will keep you playing again and again

												Despite it's flaws, this game is amazing.  Things get blown up, sexy men, shoot people, sexy ladies, you hack things, sneak around, oh and get some lovin from some sexy ladies. There are a variety of ways you can play. Want to just jump right into the action, and mass rage at everyone? Okays, cool, you can do that.  Want to pull some martial arts out your pocket, and knock them senseless? Yeah. That'll work too. Want to sneak and be some wicked ninja? Right on! You can choose from different styles (sauve, professional, joking, etc), which all affect how the fractions and individuals view you.  Getting them to hate you, or like you will have its benefits for you (such as an increase in endurance).  However, if one fraction favors you, you may have issues with those who oppose it- choose wisely! The point? Must buy.

												This is one of the best RPGs I've played over the years and trust me, I've played a lot of them. The story is the highlight of the game along with it's characters and the dialog system. Voice Acting is also very good, which comes as no suprise because Obsidian have very good Voice Actors for their games. This is also the only contemporary time espionage RPG which gives it an edge over other games that are either set in the near or very distant future, so this time you actually get to save the world you actually live in, not some imaginary post-apocalyptic one. All-in-all I highly recommend this game which is very underrated, especially if you're a fan of James Bond or Jason Bourne - the dialog system is actually built around the personalities of the 3 J.B.s of espionage: James Bond, Jason Bourne and Jack Bauer (24)

content:
er 29, 2013
												Alpha Protocol...now here is a game that slipped under most people's radar. The fellows that brought you Fallout: New Vegas were working on this project before Fallout and you can see a bit of their humor and influence bleed through. Unique in it's subject matter, Alpha Protocol is a Spy RPG, with Mass Effect style dialouge trees. While I expected to be playing some low rent James Bond knockoff what I managed to get was something closer to "Archer" than "Peter Gunn". This game has a beautiful sense of humor and a fun albeit somewhat truncated and confusing story. Make your agent, select his background, then either shoot your way, stealth your way, or smoothe talk your way through one of the more unique RPG's of it's era. I would say, give Alpha Protocol a try, it could suprise you.

And that's no exaggeration - I've done it.  The game is that satisying.The technical issues mean I can't give this game a strictly positive review, but if you can get past them, you'll find an incredibly solid and immersive game that will continue to surprise you even after several playthroughs.

content:
er 22, 2013
												I had this game for a good while, but I had major gameplay issues from the start and I kept getting annoyed and leaving it alone for months on end. I had a friend point out a couple of fixes to me, and suddenly, hello - I lost an entire night because I was enjoying the game just that much.Those fixes, btw - your default interact key [I believe it's Spacebar], should be left as default. In the hacking minigame at least one of the threads insists on Spacebar just to be able to work. You can always assign a different key as the backup key and it'll work fine for everything else, but for hacking to work, Spacebar needs to be left as default. Also, don't try overriding the graphical settings from within the AMD or nVidia software - it can break the dialogue boxes, leaving them blank and you unable to actually choose your dialogue. Considering how Alpha Protocol works, this isn't a good thing.Those two bugs were gamebreaking for me originally. Once I knew how to get around them, the game played like a dream. Clunky in a few places [combat/movement wise] and I despise the checkpoint system, but I would still happily play it over and over again. There is major replay value depending on where you'd like to travel to first, your dialogue options, everything else. Definitely worth it on sale, though not necessarily otherwise.

content:
y 12, 2015
												This is a very fun game about espionage, secret service agencies and world conspiracies. The plot itself is kind of naive, somewhat cliched but the storytelling itself is very fun. The character development is great, there's a lot of attention to detail, lots of choices to be made during the game that will have their consequences in future. The dialogue system is great - you get a mood of reply which you need to choose really fast. Depending on the reply you can gain reputation with the person you're talking to and that can open up different resolutions of conflicts in the game.The gameplay itself is not terribly exciting. The AI is somewhat dumb which spoils the shooting part, the minigames (hacking, lock- and codepicking) are simplistic and get dull after a while. Stealth is really powerful tool. I've heard a lot about bugs in the game but I haven't encountered many during my walkthrough. I got stuck in a texture once and saw AI do some really stupid stuff.Despite all it's flaws Alpha Protocol is a great and fun game. It's like reading a good super-spy book and watching a good James Bond movie. I've played this game practically non-stop for 3 days, it is that much fun to get through the plot and see what comes next, how this all will end and how it all will be resolved. This conspiracy/espionage setting is really a breath of fresh air in RPG world and I really can't have enough of it.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
er 8, 2014
												It’s third person shooter/RPG that is most similar to Deus Ex: Human Revolution and Mass Effect. The plot is very reminiscent of James Bond and other rouge spy movies.The story is actually pretty intriguing and decently written, involving different factions of spies, mercenaries, terrorists and secret police; taking you to places such as Moscow, Rome and Taipei.  Its interaction mechanics with NPCs during cut-scenes is the highlight of this game.  It allows you to chose different dialog choices that influences the story and character relationships. The cast of characters is colorful and they are all very interesting. Each NPC has a unique and different personality and a huge part/theme of the game is manipulating people to get what you want, that means acting aggressive, professional or suave depending on the person. Your relationships and interactions can also influence the way a mission plays out, whether or not you’ll receive back up, determining who are going to be fighting, and what items on the black market you can purchase. The game also emphasizes dossiers and gathering intel, which gives passive combat bonuses to specific factions and helps you learn about a character’s background so that you can learn how you’re supposed to talk to them if you want them to like you. Missions offer multiple paths, approaches and options. You can also bang MOST of the chicks in one play through, if you play your cards right (this is, hands down, the best part).Combat and controls can feel clunky, it seems like they wanted to make weapon specialization and stats like accuracy, stability and recoil matter in a third person shooter, so it forces you to ‘focus’ your cross hair on your target before you can shoot or else your shots will be all over the place.  This can make early game very annoying because your shots won’t focus fast enough, and any kind of long ranged combat becomes a pain.  The game forces boss fights, there is no stealth solution, you have to straight up fight them so it's highly reccomended that you pump up the stats in at least one weapon (fun fact pistol is over power). Regardless of the boss fights, playing stealth is generally over power, it rewards you with more stuff than a straight up commando/aggressive play, and it trivializes a lot of missions. There are 2 hacking mini-games, a word search and clicking tangled wires in a specific order. They get repetitive fast and are not really fun. The game can also be glitchy at times; there have been times when I’ve been spotted and never should have been (through a wall), times where I’ve gotten stuck in walls and had to die or reload my save, and the game had crashed on me 4 times throughout my play through.I’d recommend it if you like the talking parts of the Dues Ex and Mass Effect or just enjoy a good story driven game. You’d have to deal with the par combat, missions and maybe a rough early game.

content:
21, 2016
Product received for free
												-First impressions, will have full review on the way.-Alpha Protocol is a third-person action RPG shooter with Stealth elements developed by Obsidian Entertainment, and published by Sega. Starting off this review, Alpha Protocol was a game i played when i was much younger, but i barely remember anything from it. So, my experience was bad, and i thought the game was bad, and it was a physical copy. It was around the time of release, so it had some issues, such as the issue i had myself, of completing a tutorial, but, it claiming that i haven't. Now for the review. Alpha Protocol contains an intresting narrative, and the game has a good tone, but just doesn't feel all so serious yet. The storytelling is also very good so far, and the game is reminding me of Mass Effect, the first game, which i thought was okay, but it did have really amazing storytelling, character development, and stuff. This game also has a dialogue system insanely similar to it, and it really, really feels just like that, although, the storyline isn't as good as Mass Effect. The characters are all very well written, and character development is also very good. For the gameplay, it does work well, and it makes me feel as if this is the Metal Gear Solid V: The Phantom Pain of 2010, or an early Metal Gear Solid V: The Phantom Pain. And talking about that, the gameplay has some unique stuff, but not much. It's the precision thing, and i like it. The gameplay isn't very tactical, but it is fun and induces you into creating strategies and stuff, using your mind, just like MGSV:TPP does, except, a lot of the gameplay depth and detail is removed here. Combat is also pretty damn good, although A.I is quite dumb at times. The graphics look top-notch, even at the time, but it doesn't stand out today, but it still looks good. At the moment, the game is very good, but we still didn't talk about the only problem i have with it, which is sadly slightly big. The game contains occasionally unresponsive controls. Anyway, i still think the game should get better, as the intensity of the storyline isn't quite gripping me yet, although it is intresting, it is really not bad, but so far, it feels as if it's gonna get much better. The gameplay, will too. The weapons? There aren't that many. I like the concept of Agent History at the start of the game, too, which you select actually before you get to play it. My experience so far with Alpha Protocol is good, and could nearly achieve a 9/10 with its gameplay, specially since the Stealth works very well.8.8/10 ~Only so far.This review will be updated constantly as i go through the game.

content:
y 6, 2014
Perhaps unpolished, but still a gem.Fan of Deus Ex, or Vampire the Masquerade: Bloodlines, and their brethren of immersive sims?  Don't pass up Alpha Protocol.Be warned, of course.  The game is riddled with severe technical problems; across two PCs and two operating systems, this game has proven more challenging to merely run than any other game I've played in the last five years.However, it is also among the very best.  The setting is lacking any particularly fantastical elements, and the characters are arguably not especially memorable, but the intrigue is well presented, and subtly woven.The game's dialogue system is superb, reminiscent of Mass Effect, but with the addition of a timer, forcing you to make decisions on the spot and stick by them.  Characters react to your playstyle, and the choice to play stealthily, non-lethally, or  loudly and violently will ultimately impact certain sequences.  Don't expect to notice massive consequences for your choices, but repeated playthroughs show an excptional number of subtle, appreciated differences.Gameplay is ambitiously diverse.  Certainly, as a whole, it controls somewhat awkwardly, as the game does not master any of its elements entirely, but it offers many options competently enough.  The standard paths are available; stealth, hacking, gunplay, and melee (unarmed, in this case) are all present.  Various abilities, unlocked through RPG-like progression, offer a feeling of meaningful specialization, and nicely allow you to focus on a certain skillset.If you can tolerate its technical failings, Alpha Protocol offers an experience that's difficult to compare to any other recent releases.  It was clearly a labor of love, and fans of other Obsidian games probably know what to expect, in terms of its stability.Highly recommended, if you want to take a risk on something different from the norm.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
27, 2016
												Obsidian is one of the few developers who have earned my trust enough for me to be willing to buy their games without hesitating. I can't think of a game by them that ever disappointed me, but I can think of plenty that became some of my favorites, and Alpha Protocol is one of them.In terms of the core gameplay, the game is only slightly above average. It's framed as a stealth game, but there are plenty of character options to let you play as loud or quiet as you want, or even dump all your points into Martial Arts and become a kung fu spy if you want. The AI can be a bit finnicky sometimes, and the camera mouse controls sometimes have issues, but for the most part it's functional, and fun to play. The real distinguishing factor of the game is in the dialogue, and other choices. An average playthrough may only last 10 to 15 hours or so, but it has enough replayability to easily make it worth playing several times. Everything from the order you take on missions in to the people you ally with likely has an effect on future events, and there are enough ways that events can play out differently to continue to surprise you even after 3 or 4 playthroughs. The game features a full Bond-like cast of memorable characters, each of whom have their own likes and dislikes that can influence your results throughout the game. It really puts up the illusion that this is a real world of espionage, and it's easy to find yourself invested in the character and story because of it.The one place where the game does falter is the dialogue interface itself. The game uses a Mass Effect-style one-word-choice system, where most dialogue choices fall into three categories - Suave, Aggressive, and Professional. It's not as simplistic as it may seem, and it is somewhat necessary to shorten the lines since unlike other similar games Alpha Protocol is fairly aggressive with its timed dialogues and often may not even give you more time than it takes for a character to finish their sentence to make a decision, but it does occasionally end with you misreading the prompt's intention and leading to the main character saying something you didn't want. This ties in with the fact that the main character's voice actor isn't all that great at times, and he doesn't do a very good job of actually sounding particularly suave when you pick those options. Alpha Protocol is the one game where I don't completely hate the use of the dialogue wheel, but I still wouldn't mind it being gone.If you're into Bond movies or just spy fiction in general, Alpha Protocol is a pretty easy pick. Almost every Obsidian game has their faults due to both publishers rushing them and Obsidian themselves not being that great at managing their time, but like most of their games the faults aren't enough to bring down what ends up being another really great RPG to add to their list.

												This game is proof that Metacritic is a broken for review measurements. 72/100 these days conjures up ideas of mediocrity and most people would have lowered expectations. However, this game is anything but mediocre. Some dodgy AI aside (such as enemies not seeing you when you are stood right next to them) this game is brilliant; great locations, great story and choices that feel that they matter. If you are looking for a 24/James Bond hybrid which is not too challenging but incredibly fun, then look no further.

content:
21, 2016
Product received for free
												-First impressions, will have full review on the way.-Alpha Protocol is a third-person action RPG shooter with Stealth elements developed by Obsidian Entertainment, and published by Sega. Starting off this review, Alpha Protocol was a game i played when i was much younger, but i barely remember anything from it. So, my experience was bad, and i thought the game was bad, and it was a physical copy. It was around the time of release, so it had some issues, such as the issue i had myself, of completing a tutorial, but, it claiming that i haven't. Now for the review. Alpha Protocol contains an intresting narrative, and the game has a good tone, but just doesn't feel all so serious yet. The storytelling is also very good so far, and the game is reminding me of Mass Effect, the first game, which i thought was okay, but it did have really amazing storytelling, character development, and stuff. This game also has a dialogue system insanely similar to it, and it really, really feels just like that, although, the storyline isn't as good as Mass Effect. The characters are all very well written, and character development is also very good. For the gameplay, it does work well, and it makes me feel as if this is the Metal Gear Solid V: The Phantom Pain of 2010, or an early Metal Gear Solid V: The Phantom Pain. And talking about that, the gameplay has some unique stuff, but not much. It's the precision thing, and i like it. The gameplay isn't very tactical, but it is fun and induces you into creating strategies and stuff, using your mind, just like MGSV:TPP does, except, a lot of the gameplay depth and detail is removed here. Combat is also pretty damn good, although A.I is quite dumb at times. The graphics look top-notch, even at the time, but it doesn't stand out today, but it still looks good. At the moment, the game is very good, but we still didn't talk about the only problem i have with it, which is sadly slightly big. The game contains occasionally unresponsive controls. Anyway, i still think the game should get better, as the intensity of the storyline isn't quite gripping me yet, although it is intresting, it is really not bad, but so far, it feels as if it's gonna get much better. The gameplay, will too. The weapons? There aren't that many. I like the concept of Agent History at the start of the game, too, which you select actually before you get to play it. My experience so far with Alpha Protocol is good, and could nearly achieve a 9/10 with its gameplay, specially since the Stealth works very well.8.8/10 ~Only so far.This review will be updated constantly as i go through the game.

												Alpha Protocol is a flawed, but enjoyable gem the likes that Obisidan tends to provide. Playing somewhat similar to Mass Effect, with heavier consequences that are not only more dramatic but also further down the storyline, Alpha Protocol provides an excellent game surrounded by the nuances of Espionage.Visually, it is interesting but with it's flaws. Animations are rigid and lack the smooth transitions that many other games have. Gameplay in itself can feel a bit awkward with controls and it may take a bit of time to get used to the way weapons interact with a Roleplaying interface.With no sequel, grab this if you enjoy spy games with a heavy emphasis on relationships with your co-workers, targets, and other people as well as prefer a stronger Roleplaying aspect to the likes of Mass Effect.

10, 2014
												I tried to like this game, I really did. After hearing absolutely damning reviews, I wonderd if this was going to be one of those 'Deadly Preminition' type games where the awsomeness and hilarity of the story makes up for it's abominable gameplay. Unfornately I was dissapointed.Enemies see you from 100 meters away in stealth. Even if you're behind something. Line of sight is completely broken.The guns feel like pea shooters and the combat system is flat out not there with basically one button to mash until you know the dude out. Movement is awkward and strange as the Protaganist seemingly proceeds to slide and float across the ground and the myriad  of glitches where I fell through the floor and got stuck.The story I never got to experience properly as I never got off the first level where I had to hack a door. The minigames are also mindbengingly annoying as it seems that it was designed for a controller. Dont bother with this. Unless you're getting this with the Humble Bundle, then I cant think of a reason for anybody to play this.

content:
ry 19, 2014
												READ THIS!To truly enjoy this game make sure to save often. Autosaves tend to screw you over IE they will autosave right as the door behind you gets locked and you cant double back for loot or something else. This is my main gripe with this game as I love exploring every edge of a game like this and sometimes the game literally blocks you from doing so when you've reached a certain point. Always make saves in case you need to backtrack so you don't have to restart from an earlier point.Also, make sure to check out the FOV bind with a quick google search, this will allow you to zoom out from Thornton(you) and allow better viewing specifically for widescreen users. This game is simply put; Awesome. It's like if Mass Effect went spy on budget. It's a really good game if you like RPG/TPS mechanics with (meaningful) leveling. If you play Recruit on Hard difficulty at first you will feel truly like a recruit and by the end you will feel like a freaking super spy of awesomeness. This game has an amazing element of evolving and also its dialogue tree which actually affects the outcome unlike other games of this genre (looking at you Mass Effect...) Allthough there are some INCREDIBLY annoying things about this game like how the AI will literally do a 180 once you shoot them and spot/simultaneously fire on you. Being a stealth character is more difficult then it should be as this game is mainly built around running and gunning but it's a fun challenge and by the end stealth+pistol became very OP and ultimately rewarding. If you enjoy Mass Effect type games and are willing to look past the occasional issues this game runs into(crappy autosaves, barely serviceable PC port, occasionally weak or unfair AI) it will result in a pretty fun experience that I'll be sure to replay once I unlock Veteran.

												So far, this game is very interestings combining an action/spy game with RPG elements. Now so far it is executed very well, stong graphics, great sound, fluid gameplay..AI is a little off at times and I can see this game becoming very difficult as you progress further. The small puzzles are great such as the Lockpicking, computer hacking and alarm disabling are nothing ground breaking but add to the the game. Being able to customize your player skills is fantastic and really shine as it hits right on the mark to add the rpg feel to the game. I would recommend this game for anyone who enjoys James Bond or Mission impossible style gameplay, with Martial arts, cover and many more features. This game seems to combine a little of everything which might be its downfall of trying to do to much but so far makes for a fantastic game! i would recommend while its on sale to pick it up!

content:
r 16, 2013
												I forgot I didn't have a recommendation for this game because I pirated it years ago.Anyway, the premise of the game is pretty awesome, and not really something done before, you're Micheal Thorton, a  bipolar and slightly psychopathic spy that gets betrayed by his own agenecy and has to go rogue to save the world. Well, more like save face for America, but close enough.   I'd go into praise about the gameplay here, but unfortunately Deus Ex: HR did almost everything this game did but better.  The stealth is wonky as ♥♥♥♥ (the developers probably realised this and literally made one of the skills make you go invisible the first time you are spotted) the combat trees are unbalanced, and worst of all there's level scaling, at the start of the game, people die when they are killed, and near the end russian gangsters are tanking headshots like they've been crocodil addicts their entire lives.I briefing mentioned the protagonist's mental deffecientcies earlier, the dialogue system is sort of similar to mass effect, instead of picking what you are going to say, you instead pick an 'approach' such as being suave, joking, aggressive, etc. However, you don't know HOW WELL or how MUCH Micheal is going to go.  Cutting to the chase, Michael is ♥♥♥♥ing terrible at jokes, and is extremely violent and sadistic when given the chance.  To make things worse, being successful against certain NPCS tends to just mean picking one approach and staying with it instead of responding appropriately in a fluid converstational matter.  Of course, since it's an obsidian game, it's filled with a few glitches and probably missing 20% content.All these terrible things being said about the game, it's definitely worth your time, there's some great scenes, and a couple of interesting characters, and some decent customization for your very own secret agent.

content:
er 25, 2013
												8.5/10+ nice presentation overall, good character models, some bad textures though, could use more detail in the environment, the art is fine though+ gameplay is very interesting overall, with great variety, from stealth to fps, with some high tech tools depending on how you choose to play it+ excellent writing, some fantastic dialogues, very deep dialogue tree, as you expect from one of the companies that have mastered it (obsidian)+ conspiracy story, a bit generic , but it is presented in a realistic way, some very nice side missions that you get to choose as well+ good upgrade system, weapons variety etc- rough technically, mediore animations, generic fps mechanics, generic melee mechanics, fighting certainly needed a polish- could last longer (especially if you go all the way to the main story without caring for the side missions it is really short)- nothing else, it could be a masterpiece if they gave more time to its production, highly recommended though especially to those bored of all the fantasy rpg games out there

ber 24, 2011
												Alpha protocol's story is possibly one of the best I've seen when it comes to spy games/movies.It's complex,but not confusing, rewarding multiple playthroughs.The dialogue also comes through,as it's well written and it's mass effect-esque dialogue branch keeps multiple playthroughs fresh.Unfortunatelly,it also has the same problem as Mass Effect,as some of the dialogue choices you make might actually mislead you and have unintended results(like negatively affecting your stance with a character).As usual in an Obsidian game,it also suffers from technical problems,raging from slowdowns on certain machines to enemies not loading on a quick-load.The gameplay also suffers from slight imbalances,with some bossfights being resistant to weapons/skills you might have selected.If it's going for cheap,do get the game.The story alone is worth it!Note:DRM was removed on patch 1.1 so you don't need to worry about install limits anymore.

content:
er 26, 2016
												Alpha Protocol is one of the most responsive RPGs I have ever played. Even as the overall plot stays on course to take you through much the same set of levels, characters and circumstances react to your actions in ways you may not even appreciate without a second playthrough. Alpha Protocol's story isn't even that interesting from a wide perspective, honestly - what makes this game amazing is all the work Obsidian put into its execution, shaping a story whose interactivity blows so many other games out of the water.Many of the mechanics are roughly executed or even just ill-conceived, for which Alpha Protocol has been deservedly criticized. Even at release it was not a very good shooter or a very good stealth game, and those parts have certainly not improved with age. But at the end of the day, solid execution on the narrative end keeps things interesting and helps make the game more than just the sum of its parts.If you like branching narrative in your action RPGs, then you need to see what an amazing job this game does in both making its narrative threads reactive and in tying them all together. After playing Alpha Protocol, I always wish more games were like it.

5, 2015
												This game. It is fun. It can also be frustrating. What is fun? Why is it fun?You're a super secret spy sent by America to open a can of whoop ♥♥♥ on terrorists and other ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s.You got guns. They're customizable and ♥♥♥♥. You choose which kinds of guns you want to use on which kind of ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥.But hey, if you don't like guns, you can put skill points into martial arts and karate chop those mother ♥♥♥♥ers instead.You see this game seems like an action game. It is. But it is also an rpg. You have multiple differerent skills that you can put points into when you level up. So you can choose what type of bad ♥♥♥ super secret agent you want to be. Want to run around the whole time shooting ♥♥♥♥ers in the face with a shotgun? Whatever man do what you want. But a little side note, the combat mechanics isn't exactly straightforward. In this sense it's more like an rpg. When you shoot a guy, the game calculates hit percentages and crits and ♥♥♥♥ like that. So when you line up your scoped pistol to the face of a guy three feet away from you who miraculously hasn't seen you yet, point it straight between that ♥♥♥♥ing dudes eyes, you pull the trigger...then somehow find out you missed and the dude has just stopped being blind long enough to riddle your ♥♥♥ with bullets. Yeah well, that's the game telling you to go ♥♥♥♥ yourself. So just keep that in mind.But really the best part of the game is talking to people. Through your super spy social skills, you can choose things like whether or not you want to kill a guy. Or if you want to be an ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, then be an ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥. Seriously you choose how you want to behave or make important story decisions through dialogue. Also if you're super suave (or not) you could ♥♥♥♥ most of the chicks in this game. I myself ♥♥♥♥ed two chicks, however I probably could have had sex with another one, but I turned her down because I didn't think it was fair to the others. I'll check that out in my next playthough though.With that all being said, this game can be a fun game. However, the frustrating part comes into play with this games glitches. I've probably replayed levels over and over more than I should have because of these glitches. Sometimes after dying and starting at a checkpoint, it seems that every guard decides to just get up and ♥♥♥♥ing leave, with me running around not knowing what to do because every single guard decided to go on a lunch break. There are other random glitches that you will undoubtedly encounter during your time as America's super awesome spy.But I must say that however glitchy this game can be, it is not as bad as I was lead to believe before I bought it. Is this game fun? Yes. Is it frustrating? Yes. Is it more frustrating than fun? No. Is it worth 15 bucks? Maybe, but definitely worth 10 bucks. So I recommend you buying this game on sale at 10 bucks or under. Now excuse me while I replay this game and try to have sex with all three chicks.I nominated this game for "The Villian In Most Need Of A Hug" Award. Because it needs a hug...and a sequel.

content:
ry 1, 2011
												Modern day Mass Effect clone by the clone studio with the worst QA staff in the world, Obsidian. Very linear with typical Bioware-esque "go to three places for three quests and then on-rails for the last mission" game structure. Mostly boring characters... The few interesting characters are either useless (Beck) or are only around for two scenes and then limited to being mentioned in convos (Sis). Combat is mostly cover based shooting but gets frustrating from enemies killing you while behind cover ("realistic" cover with bullets going through broken concrete and such). Unreliable weapon damage, for both you and your enemies, results in random encounters which dump you back to the last checkpoint (no quicksaving or save anywhere options, thanks consoles) from an AI SMG spraying you and getting 5 lucky headshots in a row. Besides all the problems with it I was able to have a fun yet overly frustrating time with this Deus Ex-esque modern day spy thriller and recommend picking it up.
