content:
er 9, 2015
TLDR VERDICTOverall, I can’t really objectively recommend Alpha Protocol. It has a wonderful premise that works well in some places, but ultimately fails in a lot more. If you value story over gameplay and you’re in the mood for a good espionage story, then buy this game on sale and breeze through it on easy to avoid frustration. If you’re looking for a good overall stealth action experience, then you won’t really find one here. Here’s hoping Obsidian actually get the time and resources to try a game like this again with a lot more polish.FULL REVIEW BELOW“The only thing I can say for sure, Mike, this business will change you.” – Yancy WestridgeMike Thorton is the newest recruit in for the top secret US government agency known as Alpha Protocol. His first assignment for the agency seems to be stopping a standard terrorist plot, which rapidly evolves into a globe-trotting conspiracy hunt. This review is written from the perspective of a fan of stealth action games with an emphasis on multiple approaches. Also a fan of story driven RPGs.GAMEPLAY AND DESIGNAlpha Protocol’s gameplay is not its best asset. The level designs are largely linear stealth action arenas that don’t offer a lot of room for natural exploration or experimentation. There sometimes are hidden rooms that offer loot or alternate routes, but they are few and far between. If you want accurate expectations, you need to dismiss the notion that Alpha Protocol can be played as a pure stealth game from start to finish. Despite the tagline “the espionage RPG”, there are missions clearly designed for stealth, combat and mixtures of the two. If you try to employ combat in a stealth section or stealth in a combat section you’re just going to get frustrated. The problem is that game doesn’t exactly make clear what’s coming, requiring the player to employ some forethought, versatility and adaptability. It sounds neat, but can get frustrating when you show up in full combat gear to a stealth mission or vice versa.The combat and stealth mechanics are a mixed bag. It employs are variation on Deus Ex 1s gunplay, where you basically can’t aim at all until you put enough points into that guns skill. It’s sounds cool, but at the end you basically end up with these horribly over-powered cooldown based weapon abilities that can 1 or 2 shot bosses. The bosses are another negative point for the game. A few of them can be beaten with stealth, but most of them are bullet sponges that you have to take on directly. It reminds me of a similar frustration I had in Deus Ex: Human Revolution, where you would manage your inventory and skills for one playstyle, only to run into a boss that demands another. These inconsistent difficulty spikes are irritatingly prevalent throughout the whole game. Sometimes it seems like the AI has a field of view of 45 degrees in front of them and sometimes it’s like they have eyes on the backs of their heads. The obstacles that enemies can and can’t see through are also inconsistent. The combat AI is smart enough, taking cover and using grenades etc. The stealth AI is less so. They like to stick to predictable paths, can’t hear anything and bodies can’t be moved so they hardly ever spot them.The character progression system is very Mass Effect 1-esque. There are skills that are weapon based and the rest help with other aspects of the game (stealth, hacking etc.). Points can award you with passive abilities and active abilities. The progression starts pretty steady, but as mentioned before, by the end if you specialised correctly you can run around invisible, one shotting everything. Not an exaggeration.STORY AND NARRATIVEThe story and the way Alpha Protocol handles conversations is easily my favourite aspect of it. The conversation options are timed and almost always boil down to 3 responses. You can be a James Bond style suave guy; an Agent 47 professional guy; or just an all-out aggressive ♥♥♥♥♥♥-nozzle. Different characters will respond to different tones accordingly and this can affect how much they like or dislike you. You can use this to your advantage, making your handlers and potential assets like you for information and perks and ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ off enemies to make them easier to beat. The game provides loads of dossiers with two distinct categories: individuals and organisations. Organisation dossiers are pretty straight forward, and are mostly used to give you a rundown of opposition tactics. Individual dossiers are more interesting, as you can exploit the information in them to find out what sort of responses people would like/dislike and times use secret facts in a conversation which have varying special results. For example, you can actually use dossier information in conversations to make two bosses turn on each other later making the fight a breeze. Of course, these options only appear if you actually read the dossiers, which feels pretty damn cool for a spy game.The story itself is structured pretty similarly to your standard Deus Ex game. You have a straightforward prologue that introduces you to the world and then spans into a globetrotting conspiracy hunt. The game does a good job of conveying the feeling of unravelling the plot as you progress, discovering (or even predicting) plot twists as they are thrown at you. There are plenty of choices in the game that are all very morally ambiguous and open-ended in true Obsidian fashion. The factions you side with and ♥♥♥♥ off can have fairly significant effects on the rest of the game both during gameplay and in the story. You can try to be good or evil, but most choices boil down to picking between two awful things, which is great.The actual voice acting in this game is surprisingly not half bad for the most part. This is surprising, considering the rough patches the rest of the game has. Aside from a few specific moments, the voice acting holds up for the most part.GRAPHICS AND PERFORMANCEAlpha Protocol is a rough looking game, even for its time (2010). The character models and animations are pretty terrible, texture work is very mediocre, and relying on lighting and shadow effects to stay hidden will almost always backfire. The animations in general are pretty laughable. This especially stands out when patrolling enemies freak out for a second when changing direction. The martial arts moves look pretty janky as well. A very average looking game, not dated enough to deter me, but not exactly anything to marvel at either.Performance-wise, Alpha Protocol is an Obsidian game. What this usually means, is there are a lot of bugs, cut content and a few performance hitches. Alpha Protocol is not a stranger to any of these issues. As mentioned before, the AI is horribly inconsistent, a lot of missions like to bug out when reloading checkpoints (which are designed terribly, no manual saves), and you get punished for breaking stealth or rules of engagement when you know you didn’t. The bugs and technical problems combined with the poor gameplay mechanics make a very frustrating pile of game to get through the gems for the story content, which is a damn shame because those gems can be brilliant at times.

												Dont trust the reviews. This game is very overlooked because people were expecting a third person shooter aka Mass Effect and got dissapointed. This game is a RPG first and a TPS second. If you keep that in mind, and raise your skills accordingly... to your weapons + playstyle then you will enjoy this game. ry 1, 2011
												Modern day Mass Effect clone by the clone studio with the worst QA staff in the world, Obsidian. Very linear with typical Bioware-esque "go to three places for three quests and then on-rails for the last mission" game structure. Mostly boring characters... The few interesting characters are either useless (Beck) or are only around for two scenes and then limited to being mentioned in convos (Sis). Combat is mostly cover based shooting but gets frustrating from enemies killing you while behind cover ("realistic" cover with bullets going through broken concrete and such). Unreliable weapon damage, for both you and your enemies, results in random encounters which dump you back to the last checkpoint (no quicksaving or save anywhere options, thanks consoles) from an AI SMG spraying you and getting 5 lucky headshots in a row. Besides all the problems with it I was able to have a fun yet overly frustrating time with this Deus Ex-esque modern day spy thriller and recommend picking it up.

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
y 7, 2014
												This game frequently gets compared to the famous Mass Effect Series. To be honest though, all the two have in common are the graphic engine, the 3rd person view and the fact, that you as a player get to choose the direction of your ingame conversations. Still, the comparison can be made in order to help people decide, if this game might be for them, or not. While Mass Effect is a lot more RPG (especially the first game) as it lets you wander around, talk to npcs and aquire quests, Alpha Protocol is a bit more linear in its storytelling, since only the order in which you complete your missions and the order of your missionhubs can be determined by the player. The missions itself are pretty action-oriented, even though you might want to take a stealthy approach from time to time in order to take out a few enemies without being noticed or to move into a more favorable position for your assault. It is possible to put lots of talent points into being 'stealthy' and playing almost exclusively like this, but it has to be said that the game is by no means a Splinter Cell and some direct confrontation especially during the last stages of the game is unavoidable. Mission locations are quite diversified, while the level design itself is very linear. During your missions you'll receive radio support by your 'handler', who updates you with the latest mission relevant information. In addition, you'll frequently encounter locked doors and password protected computers, which you'll be able to open or hack by beating one of the increasingly difficult mini-games. The graphics are decent, I especially liked the facial textures of the characters and the depth of field effects. The voice-acting is great, the writing is excellent, as it often offers you funny witty responses in dialogues and also features your expected conspiracy theories and the like. Another note on the subject of dialogue choices in this game: unlike Mass Effect, where you get to choose the exact response you want to give and have unlimited time in deciding on which one it is going to be, you can only choose the general tone and direction of your answer in Alpha Protocol, while at the same time being forced to make this decision within a few seconds. Responses include 'professional', 'threatening', 'suave', 'flirtatious' or a certain subject you want to touch upon. While initially this system felt irritating, once you get used to it, it feels rather dynamic and natural, since there are no pauses during dialogues and you are forced to make decisions on the fly. Decisions in this game have a real impact on the main plot aswell, as often you'll have to make meaningful choices between making allies or enemies, life and death or something of similar weight. Characters react differently to your approach during conversations, and since the game keeps track of your standing with each character, I often find myself reading up on a character's personal files before talking to them in order to get a better understanding of what said npc might react most positively to.So what can you expect from this game? Solid, but not spectacular 3rd person shooter gameplay in a spy setting with some stealth elemtents and gadgets, engaging cutscenes and conversations with meaningful decisionmaking wrapped in a rather complex storyline. Less depth than Mass Effect, less playtime and less production value - but by no means a bad game. The only thing the game really lacks because of this are the big, breathtaking moments. Nonetheless, Alpha Protocol has some pretty memorable scenes (including hook-ups, you perv!) and I am quite satisfied with my first playthrough. Especially if you like the spy-setting, want something tight and less drawn out and prefer a more action-oriented approach to the genre, Alpha Protocol is a must-have.

content:
ry 25
												Ok, where to start?Story: The game forgets your decisions, regularly, and ♥♥♥♥s you up during the final mission for it. If you want to do a through and through American agent playthrough and perform non-lethal attacks on every enemy through the whole game, at the very end you will be randomly accused of killing American agents and have the "'merica" ending locked out.Also in the final mission, despite never interacting with a certain character who I had no intentions of harming through the entire game, I'm looking for the room where I can rescue them, then, bam! Checkpoint pops up, overrides my save, and informs me that I shot them. Not that someone else did, I am told by another character, that I was in a conversation with this person, and shot them. Locking me out of another ending...Mechanics:The ability UI is super clunky, pressing Z, X and C to bring up three different menu's for ammo types, abilities and equipment (Grenades, Sound generators etc.) However, when you bring up one of these menu's there's like a 2 second pause where you can't do anything (Dispite my high end computer), and once that's over you have to click the thing 7-8 times before you actually select it. Even worse, if you bring up the wrong menu, you can't just press the correct key and open the other menu, you either have to close the current menu and open a new one, or press these *TINY* little arrows that scroll though the menu's.As for the weapons. Use the pistol. It has an ability that let's you instantly line up 6 headshots that automatically crit and usually kill any soldier you have LoS too. The assault rifle is the most innaccurate thing in the world unless you point it at the same spot for 4 seconds (1.5 seconds if you pump ALL your level-up points into it). The SMG's will never hit anything and the shotgun causes too much collateral and just doesn't seem to do much in the way of damage.Saving. You literally can't. There's a checkpoint system, you can make it remember your checkpoints, but they're usually far-ish apart, and god forbid you make a bad decision in an important conversation, (Or a flatout the wrong one, sometimes you're given less then a second to make a choice) as after almost every single one is a checkpoint, and the game has an awful habit of putting important conversations up to half an hours of gameplay away from the last safehouse, or fifteen minutes if you force the game to remember EVERY checkpoint. (Perhaps intentionally, make you live with your decision? Sucks for player choise I guess...) I guess the game is simply trying to encourage replayability so you can play through to make the disicions you wish you made last time? But I dunno about everyone else, but I sat through a second 60 hours of Mass Effect so I could play a different character, not the same one with a little less schitzophrenia...

content:
ber 28, 2014
												Don't bother with this. I'd heard it was pretty poor, but since it was cheap I decided to give it a go due to it's interesting spy espionage theme. Basically everything is just badly executed. Stealth is too easy due to the braindead AI who will sit and stare at you for about 10 seconds before walking off. Combat is just boring because of it's generic structure and fairly odd aiming system. You can basically get around most of the areas with the standard grunt enemy through bugs and glitches - I know I did. Then you go up against a boss. These are pretty unfair and the only way you'll win is by hiding behind cover, slowly picking off each of the boss's goons and then shooting the boss in the face for about 20 minutes until their stupidly large health bar is empty. The only thing this game really has going for it is it's storytelling, with all that choices and branching stuff, ya know what I mean? It was alright I guess, but since all the characters are cardboard cutouts of generic spy movie stereotypes I found it hard to be invested in the story at all. So yeah, don't bother with this game, unless you're willing to devote some time into it. Personally, I couldn't be bothered to play more than 4 hours because it just had too many floors for my taste. However, I can appreciate why people do defend this game.

ber 25, 2014
												Overall score: 5/10The game isn´t that bad, in fact it seems really awesome at the beginning. It feels like a Mass Effect 2 with better controls, more content and more interaction possibilities. At the beginning, that is.As soon as you get into your HQ and start doing missions, the game becomes extremely boring because its very repetitive.Here a summary of the first two hours:Arrive in HQ, look around and explore the rooms in your HQ, buy stuff for your inventory/gear, go into a mission in mid east, kill bad guys, return to HQ, buy stuff for your inventory, go into mission in mid east, kill bad guys, return to HQ, ...and so on.After two hours I was fed up with the game, and uninstalled it.The teammates seemed rather dull and boring, I didnt feel any obligation or interest to listen to the stuff they wanted to tell me, so I just tl;dr´d 75% of the conversations as soon as I noticed that it was going to be a boring dialogue.The many ways to kill or not kill and move or sneak around the maps are there, but not necessary nor effective. There hasnt been a single scenario where sneaking around the whole map and silently killing enemies would have been as efficient as just going full Rambo-mode on them.The weapons feel weird. Extremely inaccurate even when you crouch and aim down the sights. So I mostly took them out with stationed MGs.Overall... meh. Its kind of okay, but it gets boring very quickly.

content:
0, 2014
												I had such high hopes for this game, I don't know why. Uninspired and cumbersome design, annoying glitches and characters that range from the dull to downright offensive make this game a chore to play. The fact that players need to keep their reticules perfectly still for several agonizing seconds to gain accuracy while the opponents bob and weave through cover is frustrating. The decision to force players to specialize and force them into cookie cutter situations anyway is pants-crappingly ♥♥♥♥♥♥, because it forces the player to completely respec their stealth specialist into an assault trooper every time a boss rolls around. Sticky cover ruins the gunfights. The writing suggests a mind-numbingly simple view of world politics where the question whether the ends justify the means doesn't even come up. The illusion of choice basically comes down to what kind of ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ you want to be. The plot doesn't connect to any sense of impact or urgency, because characters run a gamut of paperthin stereotypes. Women in particular seem to have little depth, with boosting the male player's ego as their main function. A comparison with old school Bond movies is apt, except that Alpha Protocol seems to take itself more seriously. maybe it's that AP takes place in a realistic setting, but I can't shake the thought that protagonist Mike Thornton is a sociopath no matter how you play him. I tried to play him as a decent human being but the game just doesn't allow that. Some of the dialogue options are openly misogynistic, despite being labeled 'joking'. If that is how the writers think, then that's ♥♥♥♥ed up. Even at a discount, this was a mistake to buy.

content:
er 13, 2016
												I have to say, I really wanted to like this game.There certainly are a lot of compelling, well done mechanics of the game, but they don't seem to flow together very well.The combat is incredibly repetitve, the cover and aiming systems are occasionally finnicky and annoying. My biggest concern with combat is the viewport. The field of view makes it very difficult to scan the area and locate all of the enemies. Meanwhile, the all know your exact location if there is an alarm going off. Part of a stealth game is the ability to have information about your environment and the enemy, and I can't tell you how many times I set off an alarm because I couldn't see a guard walking around a corner as I climbed some stairs. The story was somewhat derivative, but the choices effects on the storyline were very well done. That said, the dialogue system feels a bit clunky. First of all, you usually have to make your decision before the other person has even finished talking, so it doesn't feel like you're responding, but rather choosing a stance before you know what's happening. There is also a perk you get for choosing one of each stance in a conversation. Interestingly, the left, top, and right choices seem to be hard coded to a type,  there are a few times where the three options are not related to a personality but are just collecting various intel about the upcoming mission, but you can still get the perk that way. There are also many characters who show up once and seem super important and then never have any effect on the story.Lastly, the main character's writing/voiceacting is AWFUL. I can't stress enough how forced all of his lines were and how his tone failed to fit the moment. Very often I regretted some of my dialogue choices not because of what they were but because of how dull the character was saying them. When you choose to execute Nasri in Saudi Arabia, Mike says, in such a dull voice "Ooops, looks like the comm line is dead" or something equally stupid. This is the first time I realized how bad the voice acting was.

content:

												TL;DR - Clunky interface, don't recommend.It took me 75 minutes to get through the tutorial and one of the training missions.  I spent about 20 of those 75 minutes trying to figure out the awful hacking mini-game.  How someone could design a mess like that and then think it's a good idea is baffling.I should have quit after the hacking tutorial, but I had heard this was a good RPG, so I pressed on.  The next thing I know I'm doing the grenade training mission and getting beat up by all the guards I had knocked out during the tutorial.  I tried fighting back but I couldn't figure out the magic keys on my keyboard to throw a punch.  Spacebar?  F key? RMB?  Don't know.There is also apparently some kind of reputation system, however the dialog options are only on the screen for about 2 seconds giving you no time to read and process what option to choose.  Again, how can a designer think this is a good idea.I finally gave up and went back to XCOM 2.

content:
22, 2015
												A wicked good story-based game. It pays a lot of attention to detail and really goes the distance in terms of changing stuff based on what you do in game. Not to mention the game will track stuff like "orphans created" and "hospital bills". The gameplay is pretty alright, not much to brag about but perfectly servicable for the most part.It's not without it's flaws though. The dialogue system, which is a really important part of the game, is even more vague than the mass effect dialogue wheel with a time limit. You're stuck chosing words based on stances (Professional, suave) and sometimes it'll only give you a second to choose when you actually hear the question itself. Plus I ran into a few bugs, one in particular was because I ran into a door at the wrong time, causing the game to think I did something that I did not, and it was brought up several times in game.But still, I had fun with it and the story system makes up for those flaws. I recommend getting it while it's on sale.

content:
y 1, 2016
												The game can be best described as a very poor version of Splinter Cell Blacklist. Storyline is similar, but still interesting. Minor flaws and bugs, but still enjoyable. If you played Blacklist already, you may be disappointed. Also, the game is extremely linear.I would actually recommend this game if not difficulty fluctuations. Some parts of the game are so trivial that it is actually slightly boring, while some fights are so difficult that after trying it for a couple of hours and reading tutorials, I still couldn't beat it. There are also no console commands, I had to modify game files to change enemies' statistics...Good things dialogues choices are quite interesting - there is a short timer when you have to choose a type of response (e.g. aggressive or professional), dialogues seem natural with no long pauses for the player to think different actions and dialogue options affect how other characters like you and how they behave, you can sometimes even talk with the enemies and avoid the fight by choosing right path there are a couple of different skills to choose from different actions give perks which give various permanent bonuses there is a decent choice of items and weapons/armors weapons/armors can be modified you can buy intel for missions which unlocks extra objectives, dead drops or just make the mission easierBad things a lot of minor interface bugs some parts of interface are quite impractical, e.g. if there are two scrollable lists visible, the mouse wheel is always used to scroll one of them, while the other has to be scrolled by pressing arrows on the screen, which scrolls very slowly dialogue choices, which at the beginning seemed interesting, get annoying over time as you have no clue what your character will actually say no bodies hiding, they just disappear, enemies ignore them there is stealth but no crawling maps are incredibly linear, split into stand-alone areas: you cannot freely travel between areas - doors permanently close behind you or you jump over the fence but you cannot jump over it back enemies do not go between these areas - if one area is outside the building and the other inside, you can throw grenades on top of the building and when you enter it, none of the enemies will be on alert. There are almost no benefits of playing stealth enemies from previous areas disappear when you go into next area even "time critical" missions have no actual time limit and the warnings "they are almost here, hurry!" are tied to these areas (e.g. when you enter it or kill last enemy) very static world, you cannot destroy anything with explosives, you cannnot jump over crates or any obstacles, there are only a couple of predefined spots where you can do so you cannot change firing mode of weapons, assault rifle always shoots in 3-burst enemies don't react properly when being hit, if you shot enemy from behind, the moment you shoot he will immediately turn round into firing position (without any animation of actually turning) and start shooting, he won't get confused and generally behaves as if he never got hit and wasn't wounded headshots don't kill enemies, it's just like hitting them in the leg, although they deal a bit of extra damage difficulty - some fights are incredibly difficult/impossible to beat terrible hand-to-hand, no blocking, no dodging other than just moving... you cannot pick up enemies' weapons, even after you get captured in one mission you have to go through ~5 armed enemies with just your hands before you pick up your gear

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
er 30, 2015
												I really can't say too much since I barely got started in the game, but if you're looking for a good stealth game, then you won't find one here. Two of the golden rules of stealth game design is to not have enemies spot you if they only see a part of you for less than a second, and that the alarm doesn't immediately go off if you have been spotted so that you have chance to silence the guard. This game botches both of those things, along with having annoying characters and stiff controls.After I got to the game hub I started with doing the espionage training, which went alright except for me getting detected by one of the guards. I tried again and happened to do the exact same mistake, and I ended up with the same score of 88 points. The next time I wanted to rush it more, but got detected by the first camera, so I decided to leg it to the end to quickly restart. I fisticuffed both guards after each of them had raised the alarm, and I got spotted by each and every camera, but even so I ended up with a score of 133. [b1]F-cking. What.[/b1] So apparently [b1]stealth[/b1] doesn't matter in the [b1]stealth[/b1] evaluation mission.I then tried the extra credit course for espionage which involved me backtracking to the start of the game. It went swimmingly up until I got back to the last room of the assignment, where the guards had been redeployed 30 seconds after me emptying the room. I wasn't expecting the game to be a ♥♥♥♥ like that and my carelessness had the guard spot my right thigh for half a second before opening fire and immediately sounding the alarm. I tried to flank him through a sideroom, but he was already shooting at me the moment I opened the door, and I was gunned to death. So the stealth's absolute ♥♥♥♥. The camera is stiff. I chose to play with a gamepad, but you get two speeds: brisk walking pace and a slight run/fast jog which also feels stiff. The character animations are really stiff and unnatural, I am almost assuming that they didn't use mocap for it. The gunplay also feels extremely stiffEvery aspect of the gameplay controls like ♥♥♥♥, and I don't even mind the Mako in Mass Effect.I really like Obsidian though; Fallout New Vegas is one of my favourite games ever, and I can overlook the technical flaws and re-use of assets just because the world, story and dialogue is so good, but this game loses points for that as well with the main character probably being the most annoying ♥♥♥♥♥♥ in videogaming history. Every line of dialogue is just so annoying that I started choosing the "professional" dialogue option as often as I could, but even with that he goes off with annoying quips. He is like a mix between the suave and charming James Bond but with the delivery and attitude of an entitled arrogant tosser who just begs to get his teeth kicked in just with his smug grin.Speaking of the dialogue, the dialogue wheel is even worse than the one in Fallout 4, since since that game is atleast a bit more clear if you're going to say something ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ or not.Originally posted by Yahtzee: The dialogue system gives you about one second to pick a conversational attitude that is summed up in one word, and it's often hard to decipher. You might be talking to a sexy lady, for e.g., when suddenly an option comes up reading, say, "Trousers." And there's no way of knowing if this means the poncemaster general will change the conversation to the subject of trousers or draw attention to a specific pair of trousers sneaking up behind them or whatever. So you select it out of panic, whereupon El Ponco promptly pulls his trousers down and slaps his bum while mooing like a lost calf, spoiling your reputation with the character somewhat.  Yahtzee's review  feels damn pretty spot-on from as far as I've played, even though he often speaks in hyperbole for comedic effect.But then again, I barely got started in the game, so maybe it gets good once you get in to it, but I really can't see the appeal except for the RPG elements, which seem alright so far.I am glad that I bought this on sale, because otherwise I'd be itching for a refund of this. Maybe I'll give it a shot some other time, but I don't find that very likely.

content:
er 30, 2015
												Buggy, linear, and generally not as open as it advertises. The game says you can solve problems with any number of different approaches, from Stealth, to gadet use, to open combat. However, in reality the game is obviously meant to be a stealth game. If you try playing it like a shooter (running around, using cover, shotgunning it up) you can beat the game, but you will fail a ton of secondary objectives. Almost every mission the game is telling you to sneak around and not be seen, so why are shotguns, uzis, and assault rifles available to the player when the game really, really wants you to use a silenced pistol (or fists I suppose)?All-in-all a mediocre game with very little room for customization and character building. I never felt like I was the Agent, I just felt like I was watching his story.

content:
, 2013
												Before Alpha Protocol, I didn't know Obsidian Entertainment existed. I didn't know they developed Star Wars: Knights of the Old Republic II, I didn't know they made Fallout: New Vegas, and I didn't know they created the Neverwinter Nights series. Heck, it wasn't until my second playthrough of Alpha Protcol almost half a year later that I discovered how much I really, really like this game.Obsidian Entertainment is best known for being the developer other developers hand their franchises to when they hit a creative rut. Bioware handed them Knights of the Old Republic, and Bethesda handed them Fallout. In both cases, Obsidian took those franchises and surpassed the original games.Alpha Protocol, while technically released after Fallout: New Vegas, could be seen as Obsidian's first original IP since Neverwinter Nights, and boy is it an ambitious one. Alpha Protocol is an action-y/stealth-y/gadget-y/spy-y with aspirations to being everything that Mass Effect promised to be. It plays like a movie, emphasizes player choice, and offers a diverse number of playstyles.It comes within micrometers of being one of my favorite games. It's so close to being perfect that I can almost smell it. With some tweaking, the stealth could be great, the shooting fun, and the storyline fascinating. Unfortunately, small things muck up the gameplay. Stealth is hampered by the lack of attention the boss battles pay to it, alongside inconsistent NPC fields of view. The story is... well, while it's very nicely presented, it tends to be an incomprehensible mess. I didn't have much of an idea what was going on until my second playthrough.But despite the flaws, Alpha Protocol is very, very good. For all its flaws, it's an ambitious game, and it earns an easy recommendation from me.

content:
8, 2015
												Oh damn you Obsidian for the hate/love relationship I have with your games.49% of me wants to recommend this game and 51% not to. I will do the democratic thing and not recommend it, but I will list some of the pros and cons which constitute these numbers below:Pros - why 49% of me would recommend it- Well written story, characters, dialogue- It really manages to make you feel like a spy most of the times- It has some really interesting and original ideas- It has some great RPG mechanics- You should play it at least to see that Obsidian can come up with some cool stuffCons- why 51% of me would not recommend it- Buggy- Gameplay is terrible... in an age of third person shooters... Obsidian failed to pull off decent basic 3rd person shooter mechanics- Mechanics are not really balanced- Some loose ends... aka you don't see the consequences of some of your decisions- I found the ending to be really badAll in all, if you are curious, you should definitelly pick it up for a sale. At the very least it might help Obidian hire some programmers and designers who can actually design a game around what I think are some very cool ideas they have. You can't make a good game with just good writing tho'.

content:
, 2013
												Before Alpha Protocol, I didn't know Obsidian Entertainment existed. I didn't know they developed Star Wars: Knights of the Old Republic II, I didn't know they made Fallout: New Vegas, and I didn't know they created the Neverwinter Nights series. Heck, it wasn't until my second playthrough of Alpha Protcol almost half a year later that I discovered how much I really, really like this game.Obsidian Entertainment is best known for being the developer other developers hand their franchises to when they hit a creative rut. Bioware handed them Knights of the Old Republic, and Bethesda handed them Fallout. In both cases, Obsidian took those franchises and surpassed the original games.Alpha Protocol, while technically released after Fallout: New Vegas, could be seen as Obsidian's first original IP since Neverwinter Nights, and boy is it an ambitious one. Alpha Protocol is an action-y/stealth-y/gadget-y/spy-y with aspirations to being everything that Mass Effect promised to be. It plays like a movie, emphasizes player choice, and offers a diverse number of playstyles.It comes within micrometers of being one of my favorite games. It's so close to being perfect that I can almost smell it. With some tweaking, the stealth could be great, the shooting fun, and the storyline fascinating. Unfortunately, small things muck up the gameplay. Stealth is hampered by the lack of attention the boss battles pay to it, alongside inconsistent NPC fields of view. The story is... well, while it's very nicely presented, it tends to be an incomprehensible mess. I didn't have much of an idea what was going on until my second playthrough.But despite the flaws, Alpha Protocol is very, very good. For all its flaws, it's an ambitious game, and it earns an easy recommendation from me.

content:
er 26, 2014
												Shooting is functional (frankly I’m no expert on the matter, as far as I’m concerned “You point at people and they die” is the pinnacle of the shooter experience), but the RPG elements are really well thought, you can feel your character becoming progressively more powerful over time, maybe slightly OP. The plot is… Somewhat of a mess. There’s a lot of different secret agencies making their moves in the background, and it might be difficult to wrap your head around at first, especially since certain crucial info is only unlocked through different decisions along the way. BUT, the plot also adapts really well to the decisions you make along the way, and your play style. It feels like your actions carry weight, and the plot develops accordingly. While the final level plays the same, your character might have an entirely different motivation, and the final boss might be entirely different people. It adds to the replayabitliy, and I think the game truly shines only on the second play through. Overall, I recommend Alpha Protocol. It offers a nice blend of stealth and shooter, and the RPG elements complement either playstyle.

, 2015
												Started a game on hard and painstakingly stealthed my way through most of the game. A random boss fight occurs. Bosses are immune to being stabbed in the throat, because a$$holes don't have throats (or something). A fully charged shotgun blast point blank to the face (yes you can charge a shotgun, put your hand down) took away 1/4 of his REGENERATING ARMOR which was roughly 1/20 the size of his health. He could kill me with four shots from his pistol and could summon troops from the janitor's closet. So I thought to myself, fine, I've been beaten, I'll lower the difficulty OH WAIT NO I ♥♥♥♥ING WON'T because you can't change difficulty mid-story. So, I guess what I'm saying is...NEVER EVER PLAY THIS

content:
28, 2013
												By far, one of the best Obsidian games I've ever played. Definitely the buggiest, glitchiest game I have ever played... so far... Yet this game still manages to be amazing. Truly an espionage RPG and truly an RPG worth having. If a sequel were on Kickstarter, I would donate all money I could spare just to ensure it would reach PCs and consoles. I loved every minute of this game. The spy action-RPG we all deserve.+ Great espionage game+ Action RPG elements are solid+ Fun stealth+ Superb story+ Graphics are pretty good+ Great soundtrack+ Terrific voice acting+ Decisions feel imactful+ All the sex Michael (and you) desire in a totally PG-13 James Bond fashion- Controls aren't that good- Hacking minigame- Not enough customization options to make your Michael stand out- Pistol is the only thing you need- One of the glitchiest games I've ever had the honor of playing- Enemy AI is pretty bad more often than not
